ORG held that LAW ( j ) of LAW infringed the right to be presumed innocent because it allowed consequences to be drawn for the purposes of labour law even before guilt had been established by a final decision and did so entirely independently of the grounds for placing the suspect in pre - trial detention .

In ORG view , the primary purpose of LAW j ) of LAW was to protect the employer from the potentially adverse effects of an employee ’s prolonged absence from work and resulting failure to fulfil his contractual obligations .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( j ) of the Labour Code provided , at the material time , that an employer could dismiss an employee if his detention exceeded DATE . The new FAC , which came into force on DATE , initially contained a similar provision , in LAW ( b ) , providing that an employer could dismiss an employee if he was in pre - trial detention for DATE , in the conditions set forth in LAW . The DATE period was reduced to DATE by Government Ordinance no . CARDINAL amending LAW .

CARDINAL . Regarding pre - trial detention , LAW in force at the relevant time provided that over and above a period of DATE , during which the public prosecutor ’s office had power , at that time , to issue a detention order , any extension of the period of pre - trial detention had to be ordered exclusively by a court . At the material time Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure was worded as follows :

“ The investigation file shall be lodged by the prosecutor [ with the court ] DATE prior to the hearing and may be consulted by the lawyer on request . The defendant shall be brought before the court , assisted by a lawyer . ... If the court allows a request to extend [ the period of detention ] , this shall not exceed DATE . The prosecutor or accused may appeal against a decision on a preliminary question of law in which the court has ruled on an extension of the period of pre - trial detention . The time - limit for appealing is DATE and shall run from the date of delivery of judgment for those who are present at trial and from the date of service for those who are not . An appeal against a decision extending the period of pre - trial detention shall not have suspensive effect ... The court may allow further requests for an extension of the period of pre - trial detention , but no period shall exceed DATE . ”

CARDINAL . Since the adoption of Government Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE the public prosecutor ’s office no longer has power to order the pre - trial detention of a person accused of having committed an offence . Only an independent and impartial tribunal may order pre - trial detention or an extension thereof , by a reasoned decision , amenable to appeal , taken after hearing submissions from the accused in the presence of his lawyer .
